game.deck: The definitive version of arcade-style shoot-'em-up Darius Burst, containing the enhancements from the Another Chronicle EX arcade version as well as new content.
game.description:
Overview

Darius Burst: Chronicle Saviours is a sci-fi shoot 'em up developed by Pyramid for PC and PlayStation platforms. It contains a port of the arcade game Darius Burst: Another Chronicle EX -- which in itself was an updated and expanded version of Darius Burst for the PSP -- in addition to a large amount of new content created specifically for the home version.

Gameplay

Like all games in the franchise, Darius Burst: Chronicle Saviours is a horizontally-oriented shoot-'em-up. The player ship travels from left to right, shooting through hordes of enemies, collecting power-ups, and fighting gigantic aquatic-themed bosses.

The "AC Mode" of Darius Burst: Chronicle Saviours includes an ultra-wide playfield, due to the fact that the arcade release of Another Chronicle featured a very large 32:9 ultra-widescreen display. While the gameplay area is letterboxed on PS4 and Vita to compensate, the PC release also includes support for a true 32:9 dual-monitor mode by using two 16:9 displays.

Branching stage routes -- another Darius series staple -- also make their return, allowing new stages to be experienced every time you play the game.

The PS4 and PC versions include support for four-player local multiplayer.

Modes

  • AC Mode: A collection of modes based on the arcade version of Darius Burst: Another Chronicle EX.
    • Original: Choose three stages to play via a branching stage select system, with 12 stages in total, labeled with the letters A through L.
    • Original EX: Similar to Original, but with a different, harder set of stages, labeled with the letters O through Z.
    • Chronicle Mode: A network-based mode where groups of players work together asynchronously to collectively clear over 3000 stages in total.
  • CS Mode: Exclusive to the home version. Features over 200 stages in total that are gradually unlocked through play, including new ships and bosses.
game.name: Darius Burst: Chronicle Saviours

game.deck: Koei Tecmo's mythical Japan flavored demon hunting game gets its first fully fledged sequel.
game.description:
Overview

Toukiden 2 is a demon hunting game developed by Omega Force for PlayStation platforms. It is a sequel to Toukiden: The Age of Demons/Toukiden Kiwami. It has been indicated that the game will feature a more continuous open world than the first game in the series.
game.name: Toukiden 2

Overview

MX vs. ATV Supercross Encore is an off road racing game developed by Rainbow Studios for PC and PlayStation 4. It is an expanded version of MX vs. ATV Supercross, with updated graphics, sound and physics, and new tracks, gear and game modes.

game.name: Paragon

game.deck: A remake of the Korean developed first-person horror game of the same name being released for mobile devices, PC and PlayStation VR.
game.description:
Overview

White Day: A Labyrinth Named School is a reimagining of a Korean horror game of the same name that was originally released by Sonnori and Wizard Soft for the PC in 2001. Both titles are first-person adventure games about a student trapped inside his high school after dark while being hunted by a murderous janitor that stalks its halls. The remake was created by a company founded by the development team of the first White Day called ROI Games and was released in South Korea for Android devices on November 19, 2015, with an iOS release on December 18th. ROI Games has announced plans to port the remake to the PC and PlayStation 4 as a VR title sometime in the future. An international release has also been announced.

Development

The remake of White Day: A Labyrinth Named School was initially announced in March of 2014 as a direct port of the original game for the iPhone called White Day: In Your Hands. The port was being co-developed by the newly resurrected Sonnori, who had been out of business for a few years at this point, and another Korean developer named Gachyon Soft. However, as development continued, new material kept on being added to the game, including redone graphics, additional story content, and new ghosts among other features that the team wanted to include in the first game back in 2001. The title was later reannounced in January of 2015 as a remake and development switched to the team's new company, RIO Games. Finally, in November of the same year, White Day: A Labyrinth Named School was released on T-Store, a Korean Android marketplace, where it was met with high praise and strong sales, quickly becoming one of the best selling games on the site.

Screenshot Comparison

PC (2001)Android (2015)
game.name: White Day: A Labyrinth Named School

Overview

game.deck: The second game from Roundabout developers No Goblin, 100ft Robot Golf is a golf game where you play as impossibly large robots on their quest for par. The game is set to launch simultaneously for PS4 and PlayStation VR in 2016.
game.description:
Overview

100ft Robot Golf is the second game from No Goblin in development for PlayStation 4 and PlayStation VR.

The game will feature a story-based single-player campaign and up to four player split-screen or online multiplayer. Players will be able to choose from a lineup of pilots* and robots with different abilities and playstyles, customize their 100ft golf robots, and play in real time destruction golf or classic turn based robot golf action.

*Five small dogs in a suit confirmed.
game.name: 100ft Robot Golf

game.deck: A reboot of the canceled Zettai Zetsumei Toshi 4 being developed for the PlayStation 4 by Granzella.
game.description:
Overview

Zettai Zetsumei Toshi 4 Plus: Summer Memories is a complete rebuild of the the canceled PlayStation 3 title, Zettai Zetsumei Toshi 4, being developed for the PlayStation 4. After Irem shut down their video game division in 2011, the team responsible for creating the Zettai Zetsumei Toshi series founded Granzella Inc and obtained the intellectual property rights to the franchise in 2014. Since then Granzella restarted development on Zettai Zetsumei Toshi 4 and added the "Plus" to the title to signify that the team is developing the game from scratch and is not reusing anything from the unreleased PS3 game.
game.name: Zettai Zetsumei Toshi 4 Plus: Summer Memories

game.deck: An online multiplayer vehicular combat game.
game.description:
Overview

Hardware: Rivals is a vehicular combat game developed for the PlayStation 4 by Sony Computer Entertainment London. Rivals is the follow up to the PlayStation 2 game, Hardware: Online Arena.

Gameplay

Players are given the option to drive in a tank or a Fast Attack Vehicle (FAV). Players collect various power-ups including lasers, rockets and railguns and will use these to combat the other players in the arena.
game.name: Hardware: Rivals

game.deck: An adventure game about a group of friends that accidentally open a paranormal rift on an old military island.
game.description:
Overview

Oxenfree is a supernatural thriller about a group of friends who unwittingly open a ghostly rift. Play as Alex, a bright, rebellious teenager who brings her new stepbrother Jonas to an overnight party on an old military island. The night takes a terrifying turn when you unwittingly open a ghostly gate spawned from the island’s cryptic past. How you deal with these events, your peers, and the ominous creatures you’ve unleashed is up to you.

-- Steam description
game.name: Oxenfree
